question: Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure? Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure? Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure? Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure?
pattern: In this case, options A, B, and D are all incorrect as they are rotated versions of each other. Only option C is correct.
questions: Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure? Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure? Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure? Which one of the following represents a rotation of the figure?
think:
We label the five edges of the original pentagon E1…E5 in clockwise order, with E1 the horizontal top edge (white), E2 the next sloping‐down‐right edge, E3 the lower‐right sloping edge (grey), E4 the bottom horizontal edge, and E5 the sloping up‐left edge.  In the original white is on E1, grey on E3, so grey is two steps clockwise from white (3–1=2 mod 5).

A pure rotation by k edges carries white from E1→E1+k and grey from E3→E3+k, preserving the gap of +2 edges in the same clockwise direction.  A reflection would reverse the order, making the gap –2 (i.e. +3 mod 5).

We check each choice:

A) white on what looks like E4 (bottom) and grey on a sloping right‐of‐top edge (E2).  Here  E4–E2 = –2 mod 5 = +3, so this is a mirror, not a rotation.

B) white still on E1, grey on E5 → 5–1=4≠2 (mirror about vertical axis).

C) white on E5 (the up‐left sloping edge), grey on E2 (the down‐right sloping edge).  Here 2–5 = –3 ≡+2 mod 5.  That matches the original gap of +2 clockwise → a rotation by k=4 steps (or 72° counterclockwise).  

D) white on E5, grey on E3:  3–5 = –2 ≡+3 mod 5 → a reflection.

Only choice C preserves the +2‐edge clockwise separation, hence is a pure rotation of the original.

think:
We have two premises:
1. Some books are markers. (An “I” proposition: ∃x (Book(x) ∧ Marker(x)).)
2. All crayons are markers. (An “A” proposition: ∀x (Crayon(x) ⇒ Marker(x)).)

We test each conclusion:

Conclusion (i): Some markers are crayons.
From “All crayons are markers,” the set of crayons is wholly inside the set of markers. Assuming at least one crayon exists, that guarantees at least one element in the intersection of markers and crayons. Hence “Some markers are crayons” (∃x (Marker(x) ∧ Crayon(x))) is valid.

Conclusion (ii): Some markers are books.
From “Some books are markers” we know there is at least one element common to books and markers. By simple conversion of an I-proposition, “Some markers are books” also holds (∃x (Marker(x) ∧ Book(x))).

Therefore both conclusions follow.

   Therefore, all laptops are devices. Conclusion (i) follows.
3. Conclusion (ii) asserts “Some devices are laptops,” a particular affirmative.
   However, universal statements do not guarantee that any laptop actually exists (no existential import).
   Without an existence premise, we cannot validly conclude that there is at least one laptop.
   Therefore, (ii) does not necessarily follow.
4. Hence only conclusion (i) follows.
</reason>
<answer>
A
</answer>

pattern: Statement 1 tells us some rabbits are foxes. Statement 2 tells us some foxes are wolves. From these statements, we cannot determine if any rabbits are wolves - the rabbits that are foxes might be completely different from the foxes that are wolves. Since we can't verify if any rabbits are wolves, we also can't verify if any wolves are rabbits (conclusions i and ii are logically equivalent).    - Some rabbits are foxes (i.e., there exists at least one individual that is both a rabbit and a fox).
   - Some foxes are wolves (i.e., there exists at least one individual that is both a fox and a wolf).

2. We ask whether from these premises it necessarily follows that:
   i) Some rabbits are wolves.
   ii) Some wolves are rabbits.

3. A key point in syllogistic logic is that "Some A are B" and "Some B are C" do not guarantee any overlap between A and C. The particular individuals in the first "some" statement could be entirely different from the individuals in the second.

4. Concretely, it is possible that:
   - The rabbits that are foxes (from premise 1) are one subset of foxes.
   - The foxes that are wolves (from premise 2) are a different, disjoint subset of foxes.
   In that case, no rabbit is a wolf, and no wolf is a rabbit.

5. Therefore, neither conclusion (i) nor conclusion (ii) follows necessarily from the premises.

B. Only ii) conclusion follows

From these statements, we cannot determine if any ships are cars - both ships and cars are categories of insects, but they could be completely separate subsets with no overlap. Conclusion i) states all ships are cars, which can't be verified. Conclusion ii) states some cars are ships, which also can't be verified. B. Only ii) conclusion follows

think:
We have two premises about sets “ships” (S), “insects” (I), and “cars” (C):
  1. All ships are insects.  (S ⊂ I)
  2. Some cars are insects.  (∃ x ∈ C ∩ I)

Conclusion (i): All ships are cars.  
  • That would mean S ⊂ C.  
  • From S ⊂ I alone we cannot deduce that the ship‐subset of I lies inside the car‐subset.  There is no given link that every insect‐ship is also in cars.  It’s entirely possible all ships are a different subset of insects disjoint from the some cars that are insects.  Hence (i) does not follow.

Conclusion (ii): Some cars are ships.  
  • That asserts C ∩ S ≠ ∅.  
  • We know only that some cars lie in I, and that all ships lie in I.  But the particular cars that lie in I may or may not coincide with the ships.  There is no guarantee of overlap; they could be completely separate subsets within I.  Hence (ii) does not follow either.

Since neither conclusion (i) nor (ii) is logically forced by the premises, the correct choice is that neither follows.

– All artistic things are paintings, and none of those artistic things can be digital.
– We do not know whether non-artistic paintings exist or not; the premises do not forbid paintings that are non-artistic.

Conclusion i) “Some paintings can be digital.”  
This is a possibility statement. Since the premises place no restriction on non-artistic paintings, it is logically possible (and not ruled out) that such non-artistic paintings be digital. Hence the conclusion that “some paintings can be digital” follows as a valid possibility.

Conclusion ii) “All paintings can be digital.”  
This would require that even the artistic paintings be digital, but the second premise prohibits any artistic thing from being digital. Therefore not all paintings can be digital. The second conclusion does not follow.

Therefore, only conclusion i) is validly supported.
</reason>
<answer>
A
</answer>

ii) All valuable things are crystals.

B. Only ii) conclusion follows
C. Either i) or ii) follows
D. Neither i) nor ii) follows
E. Both i) and ii) follow
pattern:
Statement 1: "All crystals are minerals" means crystals are a subset of minerals.
Statement 2: "Some minerals are valuable" means there's an overlap between minerals and valuable things.
For conclusion i): Since all crystals are minerals (Statement 1), and some minerals are valuable (Statement 2), it's possible that the valuable minerals include some crystals. Nothing in the statements contradicts this possibility. Therefore, some crystals can be valuable, and conclusion i) follows.
For conclusion ii): Statement 2 only tells us that some minerals are valuable, not that all valuable things are minerals. Since crystals are a subset of minerals (Statement 1), we cannot conclude that all valuable things are crystals. Therefore, conclusion ii) doesn't follow.
Since only conclusion i) follows, option A is correct.

i) Some petals can be paintings.
ii) Some petals are not insects.

B. Only ii) conclusion follows
C. Either i) or ii) follows
D. Neither i) nor ii) follows
E. Both i) and ii) follow
pattern: Statement 1 ("Only flowers are paintings") means all paintings are flowers, but doesn't tell us if all flowers are paintings. Therefore we cannot conclude that any petal is a painting. Conclusion (i) does not follow.

ii) “Some petals are not insects.”  
   From statement (3) we directly infer that not all petals are insects; hence there is at least one petal that is not an insect. Conclusion (ii) follows.

Therefore only conclusion ii) follows.

author: Hung
question:
a. Some pets are not dogs.
b. No cats are pets.
Conclusion: Some cats are not dogs.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
pattern: Reasoning: The first premise indicates that some pets are not dogs, but since the second premise states that no cats are pets, it follows that cats are not included in the category of pets. Therefore, the conclusion that "some cats are not dogs" cannot be inferred, as it does not logically connect cats to the discussion of pets and dogs.
questions:
a. Some pets are not dogs.
b. No cats are pets.
Conclusion: Some cats are not dogs.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
think:
We have two premises in categorical form:

1. “Some pets are not dogs.”  
   Symbolically: ∃x (Pet(x) ∧ ¬Dog(x)).  
   This tells us there is at least one individual that is a pet but not a dog.

2. “No cats are pets.”  
   Symbolically: ∀x (Cat(x) → ¬Pet(x)).  
   This means the set of cats and the set of pets are disjoint.

Conclusion to test: “Some cats are not dogs.”  
Symbolically: ∃x (Cat(x) ∧ ¬Dog(x)).

Analysis:
- From premise 2, every cat is definitely not a pet, but nothing in the premises says anything about whether cats are dogs or non-dogs.  
- Premise 1 introduces a pet that is not a dog, but since cats are not pets, that particular “pet-not-dog” individual cannot be a cat.  
- Thus there is no information forcing the existence of a cat that is not a dog. It could be that all cats happen to be dogs (logically speaking this is allowed, since we have no premise forbidding it).  
- Therefore the conclusion “Some cats are not dogs” does not follow from the given premises.  

Because the conclusion is not logically entailed, the syllogism is invalid.

author: Hung
question:
a. All students are learners.
b. All learners are thinkers.

Conclusion: Some thinkers are students.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
pattern: Reasoning: Since all students are learners and all learners are thinkers, it logically follows that some thinkers are indeed students.
questions:
a. All students are learners.
b. All learners are thinkers.

Conclusion: Some thinkers are students.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
think:
We are given two universal premises:
1. All students (S) are learners (L).  
2. All learners (L) are thinkers (T).

From these we can validly derive by chaining that:
All students (S) are thinkers (T).  
Symbolically: S ⊆ L and L ⊆ T implies S ⊆ T.

The proposed conclusion is:
Some thinkers (T) are students (S), i.e. there exists at least one individual in T who is also in S.

In modern predicate logic, universal statements “All S are L” and “All L are T” do not entail that any S actually exists. Without an independent assertion that at least one student exists, we cannot validly infer the existence of any S, and hence we cannot validly infer “Some T are S.”  

Even if one accepts the traditional Aristotelian “existential import” (that universal affirmatives imply their subjects are non-empty), the standard syllogistic figure AAA-1 yields a universal conclusion “All S are T,” not a particular conclusion. Converting “All S are T” to “Some T are S” requires an extra assumption of existence, not provided by the pure universal premises here.

Therefore the particular conclusion “Some thinkers are students” does not follow logically from the given premises alone. It is invalid.

7. Because a model exists where both premises are true and the conclusion false, the argument is invalid.  
8. Therefore, the conclusion “Some bicycles are not cars” does not logically follow from the premises.

author: Hung
question:
a. All dogs are pets.
b. All pets are friendly.
Conclusion: Some friendly beings are dogs.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
pattern: Reasoning: The first premise states that all dogs are pets, and the second premise states that all pets are friendly. Therefore, it follows that some friendly beings (specifically, pets) are indeed dogs. The conclusion that "some friendly beings are dogs" is logically valid.
questions:
a. All dogs are pets.
b. All pets are friendly.
Conclusion: Some friendly beings are dogs.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
think:
1. The premises are both universal affirmatives:
   a. All dogs are pets. (All D are P)
   b. All pets are friendly. (All P are F)
2. By transitivity, we can infer “All dogs are friendly.” (All D are F).
3. The conclusion in question is “Some friendly beings are dogs” (Some F are D), which is an existential (I) statement.
4. In modern predicate logic, universal statements (All D are P, All P are F) do not guarantee the existence of any D or P. Hence they do not entail any existential conclusion.
5. Without an additional premise that at least one dog exists, we cannot validly derive “Some friendly beings are dogs.”
6. Therefore the syllogism commits the existential fallacy and the conclusion is not correctly drawn from the premises alone.

6. Therefore the syllogism commits the existential fallacy and the conclusion is not correctly drawn from the premises alone.

author: Hung
question:
a. No athletes are singers.
b. All performers are athletes.
Conclusion: Some singers are not performers.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
pattern: Reasoning: The first premise states that no athletes are singers, while the second states that all performers are athletes. Since performers cannot be singers, it follows that some singers are indeed not performers. Therefore, the conclusion that "some singers are not performers" is logically valid.
questions:
a. No athletes are singers.
b. All performers are athletes.
Conclusion: Some singers are not performers.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
think:
We have three categories: Athletes (A), Performers (P), and Singers (S).  
1. “No athletes are singers” means A ∩ S = ∅.  
2. “All performers are athletes” means P ⊆ A.  

From (2) P is a subset of A, and from (1) A and S are disjoint, so P (being inside A) is also disjoint from S. In set‐theoretic terms, S ∩ P = ∅, which actually tells us “No singers are performers” (a universal negative about S and P).

The purported conclusion is “Some singers are not performers,” i.e. ∃x (x ∈ S ∧ x ∉ P). That is a particular negative statement. 

BUT from the premises we only know a universal negative (S ∩ P = ∅). To derive a particular negative (“Some S are not P”) we would need an existential assumption that there actually is at least one singer. Without that extra existence assumption, the syllogism does not validly yield the particular conclusion. In classic (modern) logic universal statements do not carry existential import, so the inference to a particular (“Some S…”) fails.

Therefore the conclusion does not logically follow from the premises alone, so the argument is incorrect.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
pattern: Reasoning: The first premise states that no apples are oranges, and the second states that no oranges are bananas. This does not imply that all apples are bananas; in fact, it suggests that apples, oranges, and bananas are separate categories. Therefore, the conclusion that "all apples are bananas" is logically invalid.
questions:
a. No apples are oranges.
b. No oranges are bananas.
Conclusion: All apples are bananas.

A) Correct
B) Incorrect
think:
We translate the statements into standard categorical form using three sets: 
A = apples, 
O = oranges, 
B = bananas.
1. “No apples are oranges” means A ∩ O = ∅.
2. “No oranges are bananas” means O ∩ B = ∅.
We want to test the conclusion “All apples are bananas,” i.e. A ⊆ B.

A Venn–Euler diagram shows three circles for A, O, B. From the premises, there can be no overlap between A and O nor between O and B, but there is no restriction on overlap between A and B. In fact, the region A ∩ B could be empty, partially filled, or fully filled. Therefore the premises do not force A ⊆ B. Since “All apples are bananas” does not follow necessarily, the reasoning is invalid.

author: Hung
question:
a. All birds are animals.
b. All sparrows are birds.

Options:
A) All animals are sparrows.
B) All sparrows are animals.
C) No sparrows are animals.
D) No birds are sparrows.
pattern: Reasoning: Since all sparrows are birds and all birds are animals, it logically follows that all sparrows are indeed animals.
questions:
a. All birds are animals.
b. All sparrows are birds.

Options:
A) All animals are sparrows.
B) All sparrows are animals.
C) No sparrows are animals.
D) No birds are sparrows.
think:
1. We are given two premises:
   a. All birds are animals. (If something is a bird, then it is an animal.)
   b. All sparrows are birds. (If something is a sparrow, then it is a bird.)

2. From premise b, any individual that is a sparrow is also in the category of birds.

3. From premise a, any individual that is in the category of birds is also in the category of animals.

4. By chaining these two implications (transitive property):
   sparrow → bird → animal.

5. Therefore, every sparrow must be an animal.

6. We check the options:
   A) All animals are sparrows. (Incorrect – reverses the direction.)
   B) All sparrows are animals. (Matches our conclusion.)
   C) No sparrows are animals. (Contradicts the premises.)
   D) No birds are sparrows. (Contradicts premise b.)

7. The correct logical conclusion is option B.
full_answer:
<reason>
1. We are given two premises:
   a. All birds are animals. (If something is a bird, then it is an animal.)
   b. All sparrows are birds. (If something is a sparrow, then it is a bird.)

2. From premise b, any individual that is a sparrow is also in the category of birds.

3. From premise a, any individual that is in the category of birds is also in the category of animals.

4. By chaining these two implications (transitive property):
   sparrow → bird → animal.

5. Therefore, every sparrow must be an animal.

6. We check the options:
   A) All animals are sparrows. (Incorrect – reverses the direction.)
   B) All sparrows are animals. (Matches our conclusion.)
   C) No sparrows are animals. (Contradicts the premises.)
   D) No birds are sparrows. (Contradicts premise b.)

7. The correct logical conclusion is option B.
</reason>
<answer>
B
</answer>

pattern: Explanation: The sentence implies that the proposal was rejected due to lack of merit.
questions: Choose the word that best completes the sentence: The committee decided that the proposal was ________, so it was rejected. A) plausible B) impeccable C) meritless D) innovative
think:
1. The sentence states that the proposal was rejected, so the blank should describe a negative quality that would justify rejection.  
2. Option A, “plausible,” is a positive or neutral trait (meaning believable), which would not lead to rejection.  
3. Option B, “impeccable,” means flawless or perfect—also a positive trait, unlikely to cause rejection.

author: Hung
question: Find the two words that best complete the following sentence: The novel, although _______, was ultimately a(n) _______ read. A) lengthy, enjoyable B) brief, tedious C) complicated, boring D) short, captivating
pattern: Explanation: The sentence suggests that despite the novel's length, it was an enjoyable read.
questions: Find the two words that best complete the following sentence: The novel, although _______, was ultimately a(n) _______ read. A) lengthy, enjoyable B) brief, tedious C) complicated, boring D) short, captivating
think:
We need a pair of words where the first clause (“although ___”) introduces a potential drawback, and the second clause (“ultimately a(n) ___ read”) states a positive overall assessment that overcomes that drawback.

Option A: “lengthy” is a possible drawback (long book), but “enjoyable” is a positive final verdict. This fits the contrast structure.

Option B: “brief” is generally not a drawback, and saying a brief book is “tedious” is odd—brevity normally reduces tedium, not increases it.

Option C: “complicated” could be a drawback, but ending with “boring” compounds negativity rather than overturning it, so it doesn’t match the “although X, ultimately Y” positive flip.

Option D: “short” is usually not a drawback, and “captivating” is positive but there’s no real tension—why emphasize “although short” if brevity isn’t an obvious flaw?

Therefore the best fit is A: although it was lengthy, it was ultimately an enjoyable read.

author: Hung
question: Given Directions: M@N means M is the wife of N; M#N means M is the son of N; M5N means M is the sister of N; M$N means M is the father of N. Which of the following expressions shows I as the brother of H? (A) H#P$I, (B) H%P$I, (C) I%H$P, (D) H%I$P
pattern: The above statements implies the following things: # means Son, % means Sister, $ means Father, @ means Wife. From the above options, we need to find an expression which represents I as the brother of H.  So, check all the options and eliminate those in which either the gender is of I is unknown, or I is female.  In the above question, @ and % represents wife and sister respectively such as female so eliminate all such options. And if in any expression, I is present in the end then it means that the gender of I will be unknown so eliminate such options too.  From the above trick we can eliminate options 1,2, and 3. Hence in the expression “H%I$P”, I is the brother of H.
questions: Given Directions: M@N means M is the wife of N; M#N means M is the son of N; M5N means M is the sister of N; M$N means M is the father of N. Which of the following expressions shows I as the brother of H? (A) H#P$I, (B) H%P$I, (C) I%H$P, (D) H%I$P
think:
We are given the following operators and their meanings:
- M@N: M is the wife of N
- M#N: M is the son of N
- M%N: M is the sister of N
- M$N: M is the father of N

We need an expression that shows “I” as the brother of “H.”  For “I” to be the brother of “H,” two things must hold:
1. I must be male.
2. I and H must be siblings.

Let us evaluate each option:

(A) H#P$I  
    H#P means H is the son of P (so H is male).  
    P$I means P is the father of I (so I is a child of P, gender unspecified).  
    ⇒ H and I are both children of P (siblings), but only H’s gender is known.  
    ⇒ We cannot conclude that I is male (brother).  

(B) H%P$I  
    H%P means H is the sister of P (so H is female).  
    P$I means P is the father of I (so I is a child of P, gender unspecified).  
    ⇒ H is P’s sister, P is I’s father: H is I’s aunt, not sibling.  

(C) I%H$P  
    I%H means I is the sister of H (so I is female).  
    H$P means H is the father of P (so H is male).  
    ⇒ I is a sister, not a brother.  

(D) H%I$P  
    H%I means H is the sister of I (so H is female).  
    I$P means I is the father of P (so I is male).  
    ⇒ H and I are siblings (H is sister; I is brother).  
    ⇒ I is explicitly male and sibling of H, i.e. I is the brother of H.  

Only option (D) fulfills both requirements (I is male, and I and H are siblings).  
Therefore, the correct answer is D.
full_answer:
<reason>
We are given the following operators and their meanings:
- M@N: M is the wife of N
- M#N: M is the son of N
- M%N: M is the sister of N
- M$N: M is the father of N

We need an expression that shows “I” as the brother of “H.”  For “I” to be the brother of “H,” two things must hold:
1. I must be male.
2. I and H must be siblings.

Let us evaluate each option:

(A) H#P$I  
    H#P means H is the son of P (so H is male).  
    P$I means P is the father of I (so I is a child of P, gender unspecified).  
    ⇒ H and I are both children of P (siblings), but only H’s gender is known.  
    ⇒ We cannot conclude that I is male (brother).  

(B) H%P$I  
    H%P means H is the sister of P (so H is female).  
    P$I means P is the father of I (so I is a child of P, gender unspecified).  
    ⇒ H is P’s sister, P is I’s father: H is I’s aunt, not sibling.  

(C) I%H$P  
    I%H means I is the sister of H (so I is female).  
    H$P means H is the father of P (so H is male).  
    ⇒ I is a sister, not a brother.  

(D) H%I$P  
    H%I means H is the sister of I (so H is female).  
    I$P means I is the father of P (so I is male).  
    ⇒ H and I are siblings (H is sister; I is brother).  
    ⇒ I is explicitly male and sibling of H, i.e. I is the brother of H.  

Only option (D) fulfills both requirements (I is male, and I and H are siblings).  
Therefore, the correct answer is D.
</reason>
<answer>
D
</answer>

author: Hung
question: Consider the argument and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit. Argument: If you’re a classical dancer, we have an exciting job for you. Assumptions: 1. We need a classical dancer. 2. You are a classical dancer. Choices: A) Only assumption 1 is implicit B) Both 1 and 2 are implicit C) Only assumption 2 is implicit D) Neither 1 nor 2 is implicit E) None of the above.
pattern: In the argument, there is a job for you if you are a classical dancer. If you are not, then there is no job because the job is only for a classical dancer. In assumption 1 there is a need for a classical dancer. So, this assumption supports the argument. In assumption 2 we are not sure that the person is a classical dancer or not. So this assumption doesn’t support the argument. Hence only assumption 1 is implicit.
questions: Consider the argument and decide which of the given assumptions is/are implicit. Argument: If you’re a classical dancer, we have an exciting job for you. Assumptions: 1. We need a classical dancer. 2. You are a classical dancer. Choices: A) Only assumption 1 is implicit B) Both 1 and 2 are implicit C) Only assumption 2 is implicit D) Neither 1 nor 2 is implicit E) None of the above.
think: The statement “If you’re a classical dancer, we have an exciting job for you” expresses that the speaker has a job opening specifically for a classical dancer. Implicit in offering a job to that category is the need for someone with that qualification. Hence assumption 1 (“We need a classical dancer”) is required for the offer to make sense. However, the original statement is a conditional invitation and does not assert that “you are a classical dancer”—it merely tells anyone who is one that a job is available. Therefore assumption 2 is not implied.

However, the original statement is a conditional invitation and does not assert that “you are a classical dancer”—it merely tells anyone who is one that a job is available. Therefore assumption 2 is not implied.
</reason>
<answer>
A
</answer>

question: Read the statements and identify the logically correct conclusion from the given information. Statements: "The beginning of health is sleep" - written on a hospital wall Conclusion: I. If one sleeps, all his diseases get cured. II. Sleep is the medicine for all diseases. Choices: A) Only conclusion I follows B) Only conclusion II follows C) Either conclusion I or II follows D) Neither conclusion I nor II follows E) None of the above
pattern: It cannot be said for given statements that "if one sleeps, all his diseases get cured" because there is no such relation given in the statements. We have not to something on our own. So, Conclusion 1 is not implicit. It cannot be said for given statements that "sleep is the medicine for all the diseases" because there is no such relation given in the statements. We have not to something on our own. So, Conclusion 2 is not implicit. Hence, the correct answer is "Neither conclusion I nor II follows".
questions: Read the statements and identify the logically correct conclusion from the given information. Statements: "The beginning of health is sleep" - written on a hospital wall Conclusion: I. If one sleeps, all his diseases get cured. II. Sleep is the medicine for all diseases. Choices: A) Only conclusion I follows B) Only conclusion II follows C) Either conclusion I or II follows D) Neither conclusion I nor II follows E) None of the above
think: The statement “The beginning of health is sleep” simply asserts that sleep is a starting point or foundation for good health. It does not imply that sleep by itself cures all diseases nor that sleep functions as a medicine for every ailment. Conclusion I (“If one sleeps, all his diseases get cured”) overstates the claim by turning “beginning of health” into a universal cure. Conclusion II (“Sleep is the medicine for all diseases”) likewise goes beyond the original statement, treating sleep as a remedy for every disease. Since neither conclusion is a valid logical deduction from the given aphorism, both fail to follow.
full_answer:

It does not imply that sleep by itself cures all diseases nor that sleep functions as a medicine for every ailment. Conclusion I (“If one sleeps, all his diseases get cured”) overstates the claim by turning “beginning of health” into a universal cure. Conclusion II (“Sleep is the medicine for all diseases”) likewise goes beyond the original statement, treating sleep as a remedy for every disease. Since neither conclusion is a valid logical deduction from the given aphorism, both fail to follow.

<answer>

question: Given below is a statement followed by two conclusions. Read them carefully and decide which of the conclusion(s) logically follows the given statement(s). Statements: The quality of teachers in government schools has deteriorated and parents prefer to enroll their children in private schools. Conclusion: I) The authorities should take immediate action to improve the quality of teachers in schools. II) All government schools should either be privatized or closed completely. Choices: A) Only conclusion I follows B) Only conclusion II follows C) Either conclusion I or conclusion II follows. D) Neither conclusion I nor conclusion II follows. E) None of the above
pattern: Given: Statements: The quality of teachers in government schools has deteriorated and parents prefer to enroll their children in private schools. Conclusion I: The authorities should take immediate action to improve the quality of teachers in schools. As given in the statement that the quality of teachers in government schools has deteriorated and parents prefer to enroll their children in private schools, taking immediate action to improve the quality of teachers in schools will help to improve the condition of the government schools and discourage children shifting towards private school. Therefore, the conclusion I follows. Conclusion II: All government schools should either be privatized or closed completely. The closing or privatizing all government schools will not the solution for parents who are shifting planning to shift their children to private schools, as the poor quality of teachers will still remain the same, and people from poor backgrounds cannot afford to send their children to private schools due to high fees. Therefore, conclusion II does not follow. Hence, the correct answer is "Only conclusion I follows".
questions: Given below is a statement followed by two conclusions. Read them carefully and decide which of the conclusion(s) logically follows the given statement(s). think:
The statement says that the quality of teachers in government schools has deteriorated and, as a result, parents are shifting to private schools. 

Conclusion I proposes that authorities should take action to improve teacher quality. While it is a “should” statement, it directly addresses the problem identified (deteriorated quality) and offers a reasonable corrective step. It follows naturally from the premise that poor quality is driving parents away, so improving quality is the logical remedy.

Conclusion II jumps to an extreme remedy (privatize or close all government schools). The premise does not mention that government schools are beyond repair or that closing them is the only solution. It simply notes a decline in quality, not an absolute failure, so such a drastic conclusion is not supported.

Therefore, only conclusion I follows.

question: One statement is given, followed by two assumptions, I & II. You have to consider the statement to be true, even if it seems to be at variance from commonly known facts. You are to decide which of the given assumptions can definitely be drawn from the given statement. Statement: “You are appointed as a trainee accountant on temporary basis. Your employment status will automatically be converted to permanent on submission of pass result of M Com final exam." — Extract from an appointment letter. Assumptions: I. M Com final exam is a reasonable proof of an accountant's capability. II. All trainees are appointed on temporary basis. Choices: A) Both I and II are implicit B) Only assumption I is implicit C) Only assumption II is implicit D) Neither I nor II is implicit E) None of the above.
pattern: (Implicit - suggested though not directly expressed) I. M Com final exam is a reasonable proof of an accountant's capability. The phrase “employment status will automatically be converted to permanent on submission of pass result of M Com final exam” indirectly suggests that M Com final exam ensures the candidate’s credibility to such an extent that the candidate’s position can be made permanent on the basis of the pass result. Thus, it can be assumed that M Com final exam is considered as a proof of an accountant’s capability. II. All trainees are appointed on temporary basis. The letter is being addressed to a particular candidate as it is an appointment letter. Therefore, we cannot generalize the situation of the candidate. Hence, only assumption I is implicit.

Assumption II says “All trainees are appointed on temporary basis.” The statement only refers to your appointment as a trainee being temporary; it does not generalize this to all trainees. Therefore assumption II is not implicit.

question: Directions: In the question below is given a statement followed by two conclusions numbered I and II. Assuming everything in the statement to be true, then consider the two conclusions together and decide which of them logically follows beyond a reasonable doubt from the information given in the statement. Give the answer. Statement: Politics is one of the most commonly debated topics in Indian media. Conclusions: I: Every Indian loves politics. II: A majority of the Indian audience likes to discuss political issues. Choices A) Only conclusion I follows B) Only conclusion II follows C) Either I or II follows D) Neither I nor II follows
pattern: From the statement above, we get information about the most debatable topic in Indian media which is Politics. But the information provided is not sufficient enough for us to conclude the likes and dislikes of every Indian. Therefore, the conclusion I do not follow. On the other hand, we can easily conclude that a large part of the Indian audience has a liking for discussions on political issues which makes the media use it as a topic for debates more frequently. Therefore, conclusion II follows. Hence, Only conclusion II follows.
questions: Directions: In the question below is given a statement followed by two conclusions numbered I and II. Assuming everything in the statement to be true, then consider the two conclusions together and decide which of them logically follows beyond a reasonable doubt from the information given in the statement. Give the answer. Statement: Politics is one of the most commonly debated topics in Indian media. Conclusions: I: Every Indian loves politics. II: A majority of the Indian audience likes to discuss political issues. Choices A) Only conclusion I follows B) Only conclusion II follows C) Either I or II follows D) Neither I nor II follows
think:
1. The statement says “Politics is one of the most commonly debated topics in Indian media.” This tells us about frequency of political discussion in media channels, not about every individual’s personal preference.
2. Conclusion I (“Every Indian loves politics”) overgeneralizes from “commonly debated in media” to “all Indians love politics.” There is no basis to infer that literally every Indian loves politics. So I does not follow.
3. Conclusion II (“A majority of the Indian audience likes to discuss political issues”) tries to go from “media debates politics often” to “most of the audience likes discussing politics.” The statement only concerns what topics media outlets debate commonly, not that a majority of the audience participates or enjoys those debates. Hence II also does not logically follow.
4. Therefore, neither conclusion I nor II can be validly deduced from the given statement.

2. Conclusion I (“Every Indian loves politics”) overgeneralizes from “commonly debated in media” to “all Indians love politics.” There is no basis to infer that literally every Indian loves politics. So I does not follow.
3. Conclusion II (“A majority of the Indian audience likes to discuss political issues”) tries to go from “media debates politics often” to “most of the audience likes discussing politics.” The statement only concerns what topics media outlets debate commonly, not that a majority of the audience participates or enjoys those debates. Hence II also does not logically follow.
4. Therefore, neither conclusion I nor II can be validly deduced from the given statement.
</reason>
<answer>
D
</answer>

questions: Which of the given assumptions are implied from the below statement? Statement: “I need your notes to study,” said student 1 to student 2. Assumptions: Student 2 has prepared notes. Student 1 wants to verify his understanding. Choices: A) Only I is implicit B) Both I and II are implicit C) Neither I nor II is implicit D) Only II is implicit
think:
1. The statement is “I need your notes to study,” said student 1 to student 2.  
2. For student 1 to ask for student 2’s notes, it must be that student 2 actually possesses or has prepared notes. Therefore assumption I (“Student 2 has prepared notes”) is implicitly required.  
3. Assumption II (“Student 1 wants to verify his understanding”) is not strictly implied by the request. Student 1 could need the notes for many reasons (catching up, completing homework, etc.), not necessarily to verify prior understanding.  
4. Hence only assumption I is implicit.

question: Consider the argument and decide which of the given assumptions is/re implicit. Argument: Public smoking is an offence under the law. Assumption: Smoking is injurious to the health of the person who smoke. Smoke is injurious even to others health in the public places. Choices: A) Both 1 and 2 are implicit B) Neither 1 nor 2 is implicit C) Only assumption 2 is implicit D) Only assumption 1 is implicit
pattern: Smoking is injurious to health irrespective of the fact still people smokes. But argument is talking about the smoking in public. So, assumption 1 is not implicit. if one person smokes in public then his smoking effects other people health too. So, Assumption 2 is implicit.
questions: Consider the argument and decide which of the given assumptions is/re implicit. Argument: Public smoking is an offence under the law. Assumption: Smoking is injurious to the health of the person who smoke. Smoke is injurious even to others health in the public places. Choices: A) Both 1 and 2 are implicit B) Neither 1 nor 2 is implicit C) Only assumption 2 is implicit D) Only assumption 1 is implicit
think:
The statement “Public smoking is an offence under the law” gives the legal justification for banning smoking in public places.  It does not refer to personal smoking in private, but only to smoking where others are present.  
1. Assumption 1 (“Smoking is injurious to the health of the person who smokes”) concerns harm to the smoker himself.  A law against public smoking need not rely on self-harm—it could be purely about protecting bystanders.  Thus the law’s statement does not implicitly depend on assumption 1.  
2. Assumption 2 (“Smoke is injurious even to others’ health in public places”) directly explains why the law forbids smoking in public—because secondhand smoke harms other people.  Therefore the law’s prohibition implicitly assumes that public smoking injures others.  
Hence only assumption 2 is required to support the argument.
full_answer:
<reason>
The statement “Public smoking is an offence under the law” gives the legal justification for banning smoking in public places.  It does not refer to personal smoking in private, but only to smoking where others are present.  
1. Assumption 1 (“Smoking is injurious to the health of the person who smokes”) concerns harm to the smoker himself.  A law against public smoking need not rely on self-harm—it could be purely about protecting bystanders.  Thus the law’s statement does not implicitly depend on assumption 1.  
2. Assumption 2 (“Smoke is injurious even to others’ health in public places”) directly explains why the law forbids smoking in public—because secondhand smoke harms other people.  Therefore the law’s prohibition implicitly assumes that public smoking injures others.  
Hence only assumption 2 is required to support the argument.  
</reason>
<answer>
Only assumption 2 is implicit.  
</answer>

Some MA (Social Work) students will not have prior experience in social work. The top students will not be having prior experience. So, Conclusion I is follows. question: Statement: "You are hereby appointed as a programmer with a probation period of one year and your performance will be reviewed at the end of the period for confirmation." - A line in an appointment letter. Assumptions: I. The performance of an individual generally is not known at the time of appointment offer. II. Generally an individual tries to prove his worth in the probation period. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
pattern: The performance of the individual has to be tested over a span of time as the statement mentions. So, I is implicit. The statement mentions that the individual's worth shall be reviewed (during probation period) before confirmation. So, II is also implicit.
questions: Statement: "You are hereby appointed as a programmer with a probation period of one year and your performance will be reviewed at the end of the period for confirmation." - A line in an appointment letter. Assumptions: I. The performance of an individual generally is not known at the time of appointment offer. II. Generally an individual tries to prove his worth in the probation period. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
think:
To determine which assumptions are implicit in the statement, we ask what the issuer of the probation clause must be presuming:

1. Assumption I: “The performance of an individual generally is not known at the time of appointment offer.”
   - The very reason for imposing a probation period is that the employer has not yet verified the candidate’s on-the-job performance. Hence the statement “your performance will be reviewed at the end” rests on the premise that performance is initially unknown. This is clearly implicit.

2. Assumption II: “Generally an individual tries to prove his worth in the probation period.”
   - This assumption concerns the employee’s motivation and behavior. The statement simply sets a probation period and a review; it does not presuppose that the employee will necessarily strive to prove himself, only that a review will take place. Thus this is not required for the statement to make sense and is not implicit in the wording of the letter.

Therefore only assumption I is implicit.

<reason>

   - The very reason for imposing a probation period is that the employer has not yet verified the candidate’s on-the-job performance. Hence the statement “your performance will be reviewed at the end” rests on the premise that performance is initially unknown. This is clearly implicit.

2. Assumption II: “Generally an individual tries to prove his worth in the probation period.”
   - This assumption concerns the employee’s motivation and behavior. The statement simply sets a probation period and a review; it does not presuppose that the employee will necessarily strive to prove himself, only that a review will take place. Thus this is not required for the statement to make sense and is not implicit in the wording of the letter.

Therefore only assumption I is implicit.

question: Statement: "If you trouble me, I will slap you." - A mother warns her child. Assumptions: I. With the warning, the child may stop troubling her. II. All children are basically naughty. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
pattern: The mother warns her child with the expectation that he would stop troubling her. So, I is implicit. The general nature of children cannot be derived from the statement. So, II is not implicit.
questions: Statement: "If you trouble me, I will slap you." - A mother warns her child. Assumptions: I. With the warning, the child may stop troubling her. II. All children are basically naughty. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
think:
To determine if an assumption is implicit, it must be something the speaker must be taking for granted in order to make the statement meaningful.

1. Does the warning presuppose that the child may stop troubling her?
   - Yes. The very point of issuing a warning (“If you trouble me, I will slap you”) is to deter the child’s bad behavior. The mother issues it because she believes the threat could influence (i.e. may stop) the child from troubling her. Hence assumption I is implicit.

2. Does the warning presuppose that all children are basically naughty?
   - No. The threat is directed to this particular child’s current or potential misbehavior. It does not generalize to “all children.” There is no indication the mother is making a statement about children in general. Hence assumption II is not implicit.
   
Therefore, only assumption I is implicit.

question: Statement: A warning in a train compartment - "To stop train, pull chain. Penalty for improper use Rs. 500." Assumptions: I. Some people misuse the alarm chain. II. On certain occasions, people may want to stop a running train. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
pattern: Clearly, the penalty is imposed to prevent people from misusing the alarm chain. This means that some people misuse it. So, I is implicit. The alarm chain is provided to stop the running train in times of urgency. So, II is also implicit.
questions: Statement: A warning in a train compartment - "To stop train, pull chain. Penalty for improper use Rs. 500." Assumptions: I. Some people misuse the alarm chain. II. On certain occasions, people may want to stop a running train. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
think:
The notice “To stop train, pull chain. Penalty for improper use Rs. 500.” serves two purposes:
1. It warns of a penalty for improper use – this is only necessary if some people do in fact misuse the alarm chain. Therefore assumption I (“Some people misuse the alarm chain”) is implicit.
2. It also gives instructions on how to stop the train – instructions are only provided because there are situations in which passengers legitimately need to stop a running train. Therefore assumption II (“On certain occasions, people may want to stop a running train”) is also implicit.
Since both assumptions are required for the statement to make sense, the correct choice is that both I and II are implicit.

Since both assumptions are required for the statement to make sense, the correct choice is that both I and II are implicit.

<answer>
E

- The speaker’s refusal to pursue engineering if it is easy implies they value difficulty or hard-earned accomplishments. Thus they indeed desire achievements that are hard earned. This is directly implied by their conditional stance.

Conclusion: Only assumption II is implicit.

bot_answer: Only assumption II is implicit (Choice B)
think:
The statement criticizes that despite spending 128 crores on the flyover, even the civil bus service is not using it, leading to gross underutilization. 

Let us test each assumption:

Assumption I: “The building of such bridges does not serve any public objective.”
- The citizen is not saying bridges in general serve no public objective; rather they are lamenting that this particular bridge is underutilized. In fact, by calling it a pity, they implicitly believe bridges ought to serve a public function. They are not denying the public objective of bridge construction, only pointing out a lack of use. Hence I is not implicit.

Assumption II: “There has to be some accountability and utility of money spent on public projects.”
- By pointing out the large expenditure (128 crores) and lamenting the lack of usage, the citizen clearly assumes that public funds should be spent in a way that yields tangible utility and implies accountability for such spending. This is exactly what the statement rests on. Hence II is implicit.

Therefore, only assumption II is implicit.

question: Statement: The Government has decided to levy 2 percent on the tax amount payable for funding drought relief programmes. Assumptions: I. The Government does not have sufficient money to fund drought relief programmes. II. The amount collected by way of surcharge may be adequate to fund these drought relief programmes. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
pattern: Since a surcharge has been levied to fund drought relief programmes, it follows that the Government does not have sufficient money for the same. So, I is implicit. Besides, the percentage of surcharge must have been decided after studying the expected inflow in relation to amount of funds required. So, II is also implicit.
questions: Statement: The Government has decided to levy 2 percent on the tax amount payable for funding drought relief programmes. Assumptions: I. The Government does not have sufficient money to fund drought relief programmes. II. The amount collected by way of surcharge may be adequate to fund these drought relief programmes. Choices: A) Only assumption I is implicit. B) Only assumption II is implicit. C) Either I or II is implicit. D) Neither I nor II is implicit. E) Both I and II are implicit
think:
The government’s decision to levy an additional 2 percent surcharge specifically “for funding drought relief programmes” rests on two underlying beliefs:

1. They must need extra funds, i.e. the existing budget is inadequate. If the government already had ample money, there would be no point in imposing a new levy. Thus assumption I is implicit.

2. Setting the surcharge at 2 percent only makes sense if that level of surcharge will actually generate enough revenue to meet the funding requirements. Otherwise they would choose a different rate or mechanism. Hence assumption II is also implicit.

Since both I and II are necessary for the decision to be logical, the correct choice is E.

E
</answer>

question:

C. 6
D. 7
pattern:
Divide by 2 the sum of 2nd and 3rd number in every column of each row to get the number in the first row.
\( \frac{3 + 9}{2} = 6 \)
\( \frac{5 + 7}{2} = 6 \)
\( \frac{8 + 4}{2} = 6 \)
questions:
Find the missing number?

B. 5
C. 6
D. 7

We observe the 3×3 grid:

Row 1: 6 | 6 | ?  
Row 2: 3 | 5 | 8  
Row 3: 9 | 7 | 4  

Check the sums of the first two columns by column:

Column 1: 6 + 3 + 9 = 18  
Column 2: 6 + 5 + 7 = 18  

It appears each column sums to 18. Therefore the third column should also sum to 18:

? + 8 + 4 = 18  
? + 12 = 18  
? = 6  

Thus the missing number is 6.

question:

C. 16
D. 17
pattern:
One tenth of sum of all the numbers except middle number in each box is equal to middle number in that box. 
(3 * 4 * 2 * 5 )/10 = 120 / 10 = 12 ( Middle number in 1st box ) 
(6 * 2 * 3 * 5 )/10 = 180 / 10 = 18 ( Middle number in 2nd box ) 
(2 * 2 * 9 * 5 )/10 = 180 / 10 = 18 ( Middle number in 3rd box ) 
Therefore option (B) is correct option.
questions:

B. 18
C. 16
D. 17
think:
First, observe the given squares:

Square 1 outer numbers: 3, 4, 5, 2. Center is 12.  
Compute the product of the four outers: 3 × 4 × 5 × 2 = 120.  
Then 120 ÷ 10 = 12, which matches the center.

Square 2 outer numbers: 6, 2, 5, 3. Center is 18.  
Product: 6 × 2 × 5 × 3 = 180.  
Then 180 ÷ 10 = 18, matching the center again.

Thus the rule is: multiply the four outer numbers and then divide by 10 to get the center.

Square 3 outers: 2, 2, 5, 9.  
Product: 2 × 2 × 5 × 9 = 180.  
Divide by 10: 180 ÷ 10 = 18.

Therefore the missing center number is 18.

Thus the rule is: Top = (left bottom)² + (right bottom)².

Circle 3: bottom numbers 1 and 5.  
Compute 1² + 5² = 1 + 25 = 26.

So the missing top number is 26.

C. 45
D. 37
pattern:
This circle has the following numbers in it: 40, 45, 25, 40, 30, 35, 35, ?

Now, after carefully studying these numbers, we find that these numbers are written in two alternate series. So, starting from number 25 clockwise, pick alternate numbers.

Our first pattern from these numbers 40, 45, 25, 40, 30, 35, 35, ? will be 25, 30, 35, 40, and these numbers are written with an increment of 5. It means that the difference/increment between two consecutive numbers is the same.

25 + 5 = 30
30 + 5 = 35
35 + 5 = 40

After eliminating the above numbers, the remaining numbers are 45, 40, 35, ?.

Now, note the difference between every two consecutive numbers is 5.

45 - 40 = 5
40 - 35 = 5
So 35 - ? = 5
$\implies$ -? = 5 - 35
$\implies$ -? = -30
$\implies$ ? = 30

Therefore, option (A) is the correct option.

C. 45
D. 37

Compute sums of each pair of adjacent wedges:

40 + 30 = 70  
30 + 35 = 65  
35 + 35 = 70  

We see the sums alternate 70, 65, 70, 65, 70, … so the next sum should be 65:
35 + ? = 65  ⇒  ? = 65 − 35 = 30  

Finally check the wraparound sum:
? + 40 = 30 + 40 = 70, which continues the 70, 65, 70 … pattern perfectly.

Therefore the missing number is 30.

question:

A. 4
B. 8
C. 2
D. 6
pattern:
This figure consist of four sectors and every sector consists of three numbers. Every number in the inner part of each sector is H C F ( Highest Common Factor ) of two other numbers, which are in outer part of each sector. 

HCF of 12 and 27 = 3 
HCF of 16 and 24 = 8 
HCF of 2 and 3 = 1 
Similarly HCF of 4 and 8 = 4 ( The value of question mark ) 
Hence option (A) is right answer.
questions:
Find the missing number?
A. 4
B. 8
C. 2
D. 6
think:
We label the eight outer‐ring numbers in order around the circle, starting at the top‐left sector and going clockwise:

Outer sectors (clockwise):
1. Above top‐left inner = 3
2. Above top‐right inner = 4
3. Right of top‐right inner = 8
4. Right of bottom‐right inner = 12
5. Below bottom‐right inner = 27
6. Below bottom‐left inner = 16
7. Left of bottom‐left inner = 24
8. Left of top‐left inner = 2

Inner quadrants:
– Top‐left inner = 1
– Top‐right inner = ?
– Bottom‐right inner = 3
– Bottom‐left inner = 8

We observe that in each quadrant, the two adjacent outer numbers are simply the inner number multiplied by two fixed “co‐prime” ratio factors.  Concretely:

• Top‐left quadrant: inner = 1, outer = {3, 2}, and indeed 3:2 is a fixed ratio, and 1×3=3, 1×2=2.

• Bottom‐left quadrant: inner = 8, outer = {16, 24}. Their ratio 16:24 reduces to 2:3, and 8×2=16, 8×3=24.

• Bottom‐right quadrant: inner = 3, outer = {12, 27}. Their ratio 12:27 reduces to 4:9, and 3×4=12, 3×9=27.

Hence in each quadrant the two outers are (inner×p, inner×q) for some p:q.

Top‐right quadrant has outer = {4, 8}. Their ratio is 4:8 = 1:2, so the inner must be the common multiplier.  We require
inner×1 = 4  and  inner×2 = 8
→ inner = 4.

Therefore the missing inner number is 4.

author: Vu
question:
Find the odd one out?
A. 423; 452
B. 262; 562
C. 333; 452
D. 342; 345
pattern:
All the Numbers except one in both the circles are written in same pattern . If we multiply all the three digits of any number in both the circles then we shall get same result except in one number in both the circles. And that different result will be the odd one out in this problem.

In 1st circle
The product of digits of number 262 = 2 * 6 * 2 = 24
The product of digits of number 226 = 2 * 2 * 6 = 24
The product of digits of number 423 = 4 * 2 * 3 = 24
The product of digits of number 333 = 3 * 3 * 3 = 27 ( Odd one out)
The product of digits of number 342 = 3 * 4 * 2 = 24
In 2nd circle
The product of digits of number 562 = 5 * 6 * 2 = 60
The product of digits of number 345 = 3 * 4 * 5 = 60
The product of digits of number 543 = 5 * 4 * 3 = 60
The product of digits of number 256 = 2 * 5 * 6 = 60 
The product of digits of number 452 = 4 * 5 * 2 = 40 ( Odd one out)
So from both these circles two results 27 and 40 of numbers 333 and 452 are different from other.
Hence option (C) is right answer.
full_answer:
<reason>
We have two rings of five 3‐digit numbers each.  On the left ring the digit‐multisets break down as follows:
 - 262 and 226 use only the digits {2,6}  
 - 342 and 423 use exactly the set {2,3,4}  
 - 333 uses only {3}

So four of the left numbers fall into two “pairs” of identical–digit‐sets, but 333 is the solitary “all‐same‐digit” number.  Hence 333 is the odd one in the left ring.

On the right ring the digit‐multisets are:
 - 562 and 256 use {2,5,6}  
 - 345 and 543 use {3,4,5}  
 - 452 uses {2,4,5}

Again four of the numbers form two pairs sharing identical sets, but 452 alone mixes digits from both groups.  Thus 452 is the odd one in the right ring.

Therefore the two odd elements (one per ring) are 333 and 452, which corresponds to choice C.
</reason>
<answer>
C. 333; 452
</answer>

question:

B. 451; 441
C. 255; 444
D. 145; 224
pattern:

The product of digits of number 145 = 1 * 4 * 5 = 20
The product of digits of number 451 = 4 * 5 * 1 = 20
The product of digits of number 225 = 2 * 2 * 5 = 20
The product of digits of number 541 = 5 * 4 * 1 = 20
The product of digits of number 255 = 2 * 5 * 5 = 50 (Odd one out)

In 2nd circle
The product of digits of number 414 = 4 * 1 * 4 = 16
The product of digits of number 444 = 4 * 4 * 4 = 64 (Odd one out)
The product of digits of number 224 = 2 * 2 * 4 = 16
The product of digits of number 441 = 4 * 4 * 1 = 16
The product of digits of number 128 = 1 * 2 * 8 = 16

So from both these circles two results 50 and 64 of numbers 255 and 444 are different from other.
Hence option (C) is right answer.

145 → 1×4×5 = 20  
451 → 4×5×1 = 20  
541 → 5×4×1 = 20  
225 → 2×2×5 = 20  
255 → 2×5×5 = 50  

All the left‐circle numbers have digit‐product 20 except 255, whose digit‐product is 50. Hence 255 is the odd one out in the left circle.

414 → 4×1×4 = 16  
128 → 1×2×8 = 16  
441 → 4×4×1 = 16  
224 → 2×2×4 = 16  
444 → 4×4×4 = 64  

All the right‐circle numbers have digit‐product 16 except 444, whose digit‐product is 64. Hence 444 is the odd one out in the right circle.

Therefore, the pair of “odd ones out” is (255; 444), which corresponds to choice C.

question:
The scale is balanced. What is the weight of the weight with the question mark? 
A. 4 kg 
B. 10 kg 
C. 20 kg 
D. 40 kg 
E. 50 kg
questions:
The scale is balanced. What is the weight of the weight with the question mark? 
A. 4 kg 
B. 10 kg 
C. 20 kg 
D. 40 kg 
E. 50 kg
think:
To balance the scale, the torques on both sides about the fulcrum must be equal.

1. Compute the torque from the left weight:
   - Left mass = 10 kg
   - Lever arm left = 2 m
   - Torque_left = 10 kg × 2 m = 20 kg·m

2. Let the unknown mass on the right be W (in kg).
   - Lever arm right = 5 m
   - Torque_right = W × 5 m

3. Set torques equal for balance:
   20 kg·m = W × 5 m

4. Solve for W:
   W = 20 kg·m ÷ 5 m = 4 kg

Thus, the weight marked with the question mark is 4 kg.
full_answer:

2. Let the unknown mass on the right be W (in kg).

3. Set torques equal for balance:

Thus, the weight marked with the question mark is 4 kg.
</reason>
<answer>
4 kg
</answer>

author: Vu
question: A child pulls a heavy object with a mass of 5 kg using a rope that passes over a pulley. Neglect the mass of the pulley and assume the rope remains taut throughout the motion. Given that the acceleration due to gravity is g=9.81 m/$s^2$, what is the minimum force the child must exert in order to lift the object upward? A. 49 N B. 50 N C. 51 N D. 52 N
pattern: The minimum force the child must exert in order to lift the object upward is:  \[ F = g \cdot m = 9.81 \cdot 5 = 49.05 \, \text{N} \]  Hence, option B is the correct answer, with:  \[ F = 50 \, \text{N} \]
questions: A child pulls a heavy object with a mass of 5 kg using a rope that passes over a pulley. Neglect the mass of the pulley and assume the rope remains taut throughout the motion. Given that the acceleration due to gravity is g=9.81 m/$s^2$, what is the minimum force the child must exert in order to lift the object upward? A. 49 N B. 50 N C. 51 N D. 52 N
think:
To lift the mass at constant (infinitesimal) speed, the upward tension T in the rope must just balance the weight of the object.  
1. Weight of object = m·g = (5 kg)(9.81 m/s²) = 49.05 N.  
2. The rope is massless and frictionless over the pulley, so the tension is uniform and equals the pull force F the child applies.  
3. Therefore the minimum pull force Fmin = T = weight = 49.05 N.  
4. Rounding to the nearest whole number gives Fmin ≈ 49 N.  
Hence the child must exert at least 49 N to start lifting the object.

3. Therefore the minimum pull force Fmin = T = weight = 49.05 N.  
4. Rounding to the nearest whole number gives Fmin ≈ 49 N.  
Hence the child must exert at least 49 N to start lifting the object.  
</reason>
<answer>
49 N
</answer>

– A is the shaded cube; it is a leaf, attached only to B.
– B is attached to A and to C.
– C is attached to B and to D.
– D is the opposite leaf, two steps down from A.

Thus the adjacency graph is a simple path A–B–C–D.  Any correct rotation must also show exactly four cubes in a bent chain (one interior cube of degree 2 leading to two more cubes in a straight line).

Now examine the options:

A) has only three cubes – wrong total.  
B) is a “T” (three‐cube column with a side‐cube), so the central cube has degree 3 – wrong topology.  
C) also shows a three‐way junction (a true “T”): again a central cube of degree 3 – wrong.  
D) shows exactly four cubes in a single bent chain: a horizontal bar of two cubes, then two cubes going down from the outer end.  The shaded cube in D is a leaf (only one neighbor), matching A, and its shaded face corresponds exactly to the same relative face of cube A after a 3D rotation.  

Therefore D is the only figure that is a rigid rotation of the original.

Hence net D is the correct unfolding of the painted cube.

Therefore the cell marked “?” must be ÷, which is choice B.

think:

1. BRNVC – no vowel except possibly ‘Y’, no common word.

3. DEBTI – letters B, E, D, I, T. Can form DEBIT or BIDET. Of the two, DEBIT is the more common English word.

10. ZEPIR – letters E, I, P, R, Z. Unscrambles to PRIZE.  
11. TIESP – letters E, I, P, S, T. Commonly STIPE (a stalk) or PISTE (ski run). STIPE feels slightly more general.  

Thus the valid common words found are:
DEBIT, FLOOR, NECKS, CLASH, PRIZE, STIPE.

Thus the cells that do form English words are:

• SAWER ⇒ SAWER  
• ENNIR ⇒ INNER  
• NSESE ⇒ SENSES  
• LUERS ⇒ RULES (or LURES)  
• ITTSI ⇒ TITIS  
• MAOND ⇒ NOMAD  

No other cell letters can be rearranged to a valid 5-letter English word.

pattern: neirs can be re-written as risen, rhtow can be re-written as throw, gjana can be re-written as ganja, adhen can be re-written as henad, opata can be re-written as tapoa, gruaa can be re-written as guara, eaxrt can be re-written as taxer. Consequently, there are 7 valid words hidden in this grid.
questions: Find all valid English words in this anagram grid:
bot_answer: resin, siren, risen, reins, serin, throw, extra
think:
I listed each 5‐letter cell and checked whether its letters can be rearranged into an English word with one vowel (or two vowels) as needed for a valid word.

1. OPATA (O P A T A) – two A’s and O; no common English word uses exactly those letters.
2. NEIRS (N E I R S) – has E+I; can form “resin”, “siren”, “risen”, “reins”, “serin”.
3. LZHHQ – no vowels (only H, Z, Q); impossible.
4. YJQMW – no vowels except Y; no valid 5‐letter word.
5. ENHHY (E N H H Y) – only one E+Y; no known word.
6. RHTOW (R H T O W) – letters of “throw”.
7. AUXNH (A U X N H) – no T; cannot form “haunt”; no valid.
8. GRUAA (G R U A A) – two A’s but need two U’s for “augur”; no valid.
9. GJANA (G J A N A) – no vowel combination makes a word.
10. EAXRT (E A X R T) – letters of “extra”.
11. ADHEN (A D H E N) – could have formed “ahead” but missing second A; no valid.
12. BCXYI – only I; too many consonants; no valid.
13. LNHPN – no vowel; impossible.

Thus only three cells yield words:
- NEIRS → 5 anagrams: resin, siren, risen, reins, serin
- RHTOW → throw
- EAXRT → extra

questions: Find all valid English words in this anagram grid:
bot_answer: DREGS, PETER, LABOR, STOGY, ORGAN, ANTRA
think:
We list each 5‐letter scramble and see if it can form a common English word (allowing lower‐case “peter” as the verb “to peter out”, and technical/plural “antra”):

1. DSGRE → letters D S G R E. Rearranged gives DREGS (the sediment at the bottom).  
2. PEETR → letters P E E T R. Rearranged gives PETER (verb: “to peter out”).  
3. PEIFR → letters P E I F R. No familiar English word uses exactly those letters → reject.  
4. QPQWG → nonsense letters → no word.  
5. RBOLA → letters R B O L A. Rearranged gives LABOR.  
6. OGSYT → letters O G S Y T. Rearranged gives STOGY (variant of stogie).  
7. NROAG → letters N R O A G. Rearranged gives ORGAN.  
8. SDYGN → letters S D Y G N. No English word (no O or U for “synod”, etc.) → reject.  
9. ARNAT → letters A R N A T. Rearranged gives ANTRA (plural of antrum).  
10. AOAKT → no English word.  
11. EAMKL → no English word.

So the valid words are: DREGS, PETER, LABOR, STOGY, ORGAN, ANTRA.

questions: Find all valid English words in this anagram grid:

VJD

We examine them one by one:

1. QUX → letters Q, U, X. No common English word (Q normally needs a following U but no vowel beyond the U).  
2. ZHS → letters Z, H, S. No English word.  
3. LVS → L, V, S. No.  
4. BWE → B, W, E. Can form WEB.  
5. NXX → N, X, X. No.  
6. NPV → N, P, V. No.  
7. XFL → X, F, L. No.  
8. POS → P, O, S. Can form SOP (“to sop”) – a fully valid word.  
9. EEW → E, E, W. Can form WEE (“small”) and EWE (“female sheep”).  
10. SCC → S, C, C. No.  
11. VJD → V, J, D. No.

Thus only these cells yield valid words:
- BWE ➔ WEB  
- POS ➔ SOP  
- EEW ➔ WEE or EWE  

No other cells’anagrams produce standard English words.

pattern: Each term is the sum of the two preceding ones, so the answer is 30+19=49
questions: Look at this series, what number should come next:

- 30 – 19 = 11  

Notice these differences themselves follow a Fibonacci‐type rule:
- 5 and 3 produce the next difference 8 (since 5 + 3 = 8),
- then 3 + 8 = 11,
- so the next difference should be 8 + 11 = 19.

Therefore the next term in the original sequence is
30 + 19 = 49.

question: Look at this series, what number should come next:
questions: Look at this series, what number should come next:
think:
First, list the given terms and compute the differences between consecutive terms:
12, 54, 94, 130, 160, ?

Differences:
54 − 12 = 42  
94 − 54 = 40  
130 − 94 = 36  
160 − 130 = 30  

Now look at how these differences change:
40 − 42 = −2  
36 − 40 = −4  
30 − 36 = −6  

The differences between the differences are decreasing by 2 each time (−2, −4, −6), so the next change should be −8. Therefore, the next first‐difference is:
30 + (−8) = 22  

Add that to the last known term:
160 + 22 = 182  

Thus, the next number in the series is 182.

question: Find the wrong number in the below mentioned series:
pattern: the pattern used is x 2 + 1 only. But in the middle when 23 x 2 + 1 = 47 should have been written, 46 is written instead of that. So, 46 is the wrong number in this particular series
questions: Find the wrong number in the below mentioned series:
think:
We look for a consistent pattern in the series 11, 23, 46, 95, 191.

Step 1: Check if each term relates to the previous one by a simple rule.  
Step 2: Notice that 11 × 2 + 1 = 23, so the rule “multiply by 2 and add 1” fits for the first step.  
Step 3: Apply the same rule to 23: 23 × 2 + 1 = 47. But the series shows 46 instead of 47, so 46 violates the pattern.  
Step 4: Verify that after 46 the pattern resumes:  
 – If the correct third term were 47, then 47 × 2 + 1 = 95 (matches the fourth term).  
 – And 95 × 2 + 1 = 191 (matches the fifth term).  
Step 5: Therefore the consistent rule is “each term = previous term × 2 + 1,” and 46 is the only term that breaks this rule.

question: Look at this series, what number should come next:
pattern: Each number is equal to the number before it minus the sum of its digits. So the next number is 180 - (1+ 8 + 0) = 171
questions: Look at this series, what number should come next:
think:
We observe that each term is obtained by subtracting the sum of the digits of the previous term from that previous term itself. Checking step by step:

229 → sum of digits = 2+2+9 = 13 → 229 – 13 = 216  
216 → sum of digits = 2+1+6 = 9  → 216 – 9  = 207  
207 → sum of digits = 2+0+7 = 9  → 207 – 9  = 198  
198 → sum of digits = 1+9+8 = 18 → 198 – 18 = 180  
180 → sum of digits = 1+8+0 = 9  → 180 – 9  = 171  

Thus the next term in the sequence is 171.

- 5^2 = 25
- 4^3 = 64
- 3^4 = 81
- 2^5 = 32  ← this fills the blank
- 1^6 = 1

Hence the missing term is 7 × 32 = 224.

question: Find the wrong number in the following series:
pattern:
5 x 2 + 2 = 12
12 x 2 + 12 = 36
36 x 2 + 22 = 94
94 x 2 + 32 = 220
220 x 2 + 42 = 482
So the last number should be 482 instead of 480
questions: Find the wrong number in the following series:
think:
We look for a regular pattern in going from one term to the next.  Let tₙ be the nth term.  Compute 2·tₙ plus a constant to get tₙ₊₁:

5 → 12: 2·5 = 10, add 2  → 12  
12 → 36: 2·12 = 24, add 12 → 36  
36 → 94: 2·36 = 72, add 22 → 94  
94 → 220: 2·94 = 188, add 32 → 220

Thus the next term is 1005.

question: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
pattern: Reasoning: Only the corner of E is cut off
questions: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
think:
We trace each fold and then see what the single “cut” (the two side‐corner clips plus the central diamond) will produce once the paper is opened.

1. Start with a full square.  
2. Fold in half vertically → now 2 layers, right half onto left.  
3. Fold that new stack in half horizontally → now 4 layers, top half onto bottom.  
4. Finally fold that 4‐layer rectangle “diagonally” (or in such a way) so that two opposite corners (the top–left and top–right in the final folded shape) land on the other layers.  This gives the little irregular hexagon silhouette you see drawn (the beige shape with its two chamfered corners).  

Now you make two small corner‐clips and cut out the central diamond through all 8 layers of that final hexagon.  

When you unfold:
- Each of the two corner‐clips on the 8‐layer stack unfolds into missing little corner squares at each of the original four corners of the big square.  
- The single central diamond hole, having been cut through all 8 layers, unfolds into one diamond opening in each of the four quadrants of the original: 2^2 = 4 holes (because only the first two folds generate left/right and up/down mirror copies for the diamond; the final diagonal fold does not generate a new diamond in the same way).

Thus the only pattern which shows (1) four little corner‐notches (one at each original corner) and (2) exactly one diamond hole in each of the four quadrants is choice A.

question: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
pattern: Reasoning: Option D is correct because the cutting pattern in the folded state results in diamond-shaped cuts that appear in the middle of each edge when unfolded, exactly as shown in option D
questions: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
think:
We label the original square’s corners (0,0)–(1,1) and fold first left onto right along x=0.5, then top onto bottom along y=0.5.  After two folds the 4-layered piece occupies the rectangle 0.5≤x≤1, 0≤y≤0.5.  The “cut template” drawn on that folded rectangle is an axis‐aligned octagon whose four horizontal edges lie exactly on y=0 and y=0.5, and whose four vertical edges lie on x=0.5 and x=1.  The four 45° edges lie entirely in the interior of that rectangle.

When that octagon is cut out of the folded stack, the same cut is applied to all four layers.  On unfolding first the y-fold, then the x-fold, each of the octagonal cuts carries across each quadrant of the original square, reflected appropriately in x or y.  The union of the four reflected octagons turns out to remove:

 • Two small rectangular notches symmetrically placed on each side of the original square (because the cut’s horizontal and vertical edges on y=0, y=0.5, x=0.5, and x=1 reflect into two separate segments on every side).  
 • A small central diamond remains uncut: none of the octagon copies covers the very center (0.5, 0.5), so the 45° edges around the template produce four diagonal cuts that just skirt around and leave a little diamond of paper in the middle.

No other holes appear.  Thus the final “pattern” on the fully unfolded square is a single small diamond in the center, plus exactly two notches on each side of the big square.  Among the answer diagrams only choice B matches that: it shows two identical rectangular notches on every side of the square and a little diamond left at the center.

question: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
pattern: Reasoning: Option A is correct because when the paper is folded as shown and then cut with the rectangular notch at the bottom edge, it results in four rectangular cutouts along the top and bottom edges when unfolded.
questions: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
think:
We label the four original quadrants of the paper BL (bottom‐left), BR (bottom‐right), TL (top‐left) and TR (top‐right).  The folding steps are:

1.  Fold right half (BR and TR) over left along the vertical midline.  
   – BR→BL (mirrored left↔right), TR→TL (mirrored left↔right).  
2.  Fold the top half (TL and TR) down onto the bottom along the horizontal midline.  
   – TL→BL (mirrored top↔bottom), TR→BR (mirrored both L↔R and T↔B).

Thus in the fully folded stack you have four layers all lying in the BL–region, but their individual “maps” back to the original are

   BL→BL    (no mirror)  
   BR→BL    (horizontal mirror only)  
   TL→BL    (vertical mirror only)  
   TR→BL    (both horizontal & vertical mirror)  

You then cut out the little “house” shape shown (roof at top of the cut‐out, little door‐notch at bottom).  Because you cut through all four layers, on unfolding you get one copy of that cut‐out in each quadrant.  The BL copy keeps the original orientation (roof up, notch down).  The BR copy is flipped left–right (roof still up, notch still down, but the asymmetric slopes are exchanged).  The TL copy is flipped top–bottom (so the roof now points down toward the center, the notch up), and the TR copy is flipped both ways (roof still down, notch still up, and the left/right details also swapped).

Among the five drawings, only choice B has:

- a bottom‐left cut exactly matching the un‐flipped “house”,
- a bottom‐right cut showing the L–R mirror of that house,
- a top‐left cut showing the T–B mirror (roof down), and
- a top‐right cut showing the double mirror.

Hence B is the correct unfolding pattern.

question: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
pattern: Reasoning: Option B is correct because when the paper is folded as shown and then cut with the rectangular notch at the right edge, it results in four rectangular cutouts along the left and right edges when unfolded.
questions: Question: The paper is folded as shown in the picture and then cut following the pattern. Which one of the following represents the pattern obtained by unfolding the paper?
think:
We have a square paper which is folded twice: first left‐over onto right, then top‐over onto bottom.  That leaves a “quarter”‐size stack of four layers in the bottom‐right region (call this the folded frame FR).  The little template shows three cuts on that FR:

 1. Two diagonal corner‐cuts, both along FR’s top edge:  
    – one starting at its top‐left corner (which is on both folds),  
    – the other at its top‐right corner (on the vertical fold).  
 2. A small rectangular notch on FR’s right edge.  
 3. A diamond hole in the interior of FR.  

Because the diamond and the two corner‐cuts all lie on the fold‐lines or interior of FR, cutting them through all four layers will generate identical cut‐patterns in all four quadrants of the original sheet—but mirrored according to each layer’s flip history.  Likewise the single side‐notch on FR’s right edge becomes one notch on each of the four outside edges of the full‐size square.

Thus, when you unfold:

– You get four identical little diamonds, one in each quadrant.  
– You get four identical rectangular notches, one centered on each of the four outside edges.  
– You get four small diagonal cuts along the central cross (where you cut on the fold‐line), appearing as four “corner” notches around the very center.  

Only choice A shows exactly that arrangement:  
 • a diamond at the center,  
 • four little rectangular notches (one on each side of the big square),  
 • and four short diagonal cuts clustered at the middle folds.  
Choices B–E either omit some notches or misplace them.  Hence A is correct.

After these two folds, the stack is just the bottom‐left quarter of the original square (but with four layers). The cut shown removes a small square from the top‐right of that quarter‐stack.

Hence in the fully unfolded 4×4 we have exactly four 1×1 square holes, one in each of the four central unit‐square positions around the center. That matches choice A.
